title: Trump's Asia tour sees deals, knee-bending and a revealing Xi meeting
summary:
Trump's stops in Malaysia, Japan and South Korea over the course of the first four days were an exercise in pleasing a sometimes mercurial American president.
With China, Trump may flick his pen, but such actions come with consequences.
He also presided over a treaty that should ease border tensions between Thailand and Cambodia – the kind of "peace deal" the American president loves to tout.
The main event of Trump's Asia trip came in its final hours, however, as he met with Xi.
Trump's mood was upbeat after the meeting, which he described as "amazing" and graded a 12 on a scale of 1-10.

title: Steven van de Velde: Dutch volleyball player and child rapist denied Australian visa
summary:
Dutch volleyball player and convicted child rapist denied visa to compete in AustraliaTwo weeks ago, South Australia's Attorney-General Kyam Maher wrote to the federal government, calling on authorities to reject his visa as his crimes were "utterly abhorrent".
Steven van de Velde, 31, was due to play at the Beach Volleyball World Championships in Adelaide, South Australia, next month.
A Dutch Olympic volleyball player convicted of raping a British girl a decade ago has been denied a visa to compete in Australia.
After the rape in 2014, Van de Velde returned to the Netherlands but in 2016, he was extradited to the UK and arrested.
The BBC has contacted the organisers of the world championship event in South Australia and the Dutch national volleyball association for comment.

title: S Korea announces lowering of tariffs as part of new US trade deal
summary:
South Korea's presidential aide, Kim Yong-beom, said the two sides will reduce reciprocal tariffs from 25% to 15%, as was agreed earlier this year.
South Korea will also invest $350bn (£265bn) in the US, including $200bn in cash investment and $150bn in shipbuilding, Kim said.
"We had a tremendous meeting today with South Korea", Trump said of his discussions with South Korean President Lee Jae Myung, adding that "a lot was determined".
Noting the long-standing tensions between North and South Korea, Trump said "we will see what we can do to get that all straightened out".
Chinese interference became a common trope in conspiracy theories about former South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol.

title: Trump’s Baffling Call for Resuming U.S. Nuclear Tests
summary:
The Project 2025 report, now acknowledged by Trump as an indicator of his administration’s policies, had called for resuming U.S. nuclear testing to ensure the performance of the nuclear stockpile.
The U.S can presently test nuclear weapons in every way, shape or form—except for doing explosive tests that create yield.
The U.S. knows more about its nuclear weapons today than it did in the period when it was testing them.
Project 2025 called for resuming underground nuclear tests, though.
And the Department of Defense doesn’t have any role in this, really, because nuclear testing is handled by the Department of Energy.

title: Methanol poisoning: Laos survivor says warnings must go further
summary:
Methanol poisoning survivor says influencer campaign not enough3 days ago Share Save Jack Gray BBC Newsbeat Share SaveBethany Clarke Bethany Clarke (left) and her friend Simone White became ill after being offered shots in LaosA survivor of a mass methanol poisoning in Laos says an influencer campaign designed to warn young travellers about the deadly substance doesn’t go far enough.
The UK government has recruited students and influencers to promote safety messages about methanol poisoning on social media.
There has been pressure on the government to do more to highlight the risks of methanol poisoning since the deaths in Laos.
Although she has a full-time job and describes social media as a "hobby", she has more than 40,000 TikTok followers on her travel-focused account.
"One was a focus on methanol poisoning when travelling," she says.

title: Trump isn’t interested in war with China. But it might be interested in him.
summary:
In particular, Xi is reportedly seeking a statement from Trump formally opposing Taiwan’s independence.
Before the meeting, one Trump aide told NBC News that “everyone is holding their breath” to hear what he would say about Taiwan.
In the end, according to Trump, the issue did not even come up at the meeting in Korea.
If Trump actually means a return to active nuclear testing — detonating warheads — that would be a major escalation that could prompt reciprocal moves from Russia and China.
Trump may not be interested in war with China, but war with China could still be interested in him.

title: Trump is ordering the US to revive nuclear weapons tests after a 33-year hiatus
summary:
Trump met Xi on Thursday in South Korea, just after he announced that the US would resume nuclear weapons testing.
Trump met Xi on Thursday in South Korea, just after he announced that the US would resume nuclear weapons testing.
Andrew Harnik/Getty ImagesTrump met Xi on Thursday in South Korea, just after he announced that the US would resume nuclear weapons testing.
Trump said little about what these nuclear weapons tests would entail, or when exactly they would begin.
Fears of a nuclear arms raceMoscow, meanwhile, said it's been actively testing nuclear superweapons.

title: OpenAI, Anthropic, Perplexity Expand in India for Next Billion Users
summary:
In recent months, American AI companies, such as OpenAI and Perplexity, have also steadily expanded their footprint in India, the world's largest open internet market outside the US.
For the big AI companies, however, "India is not the 'next billion users' market.
By the time Anadan left Google in 2019, he said that India was the single largest market for all the company's largest products.
India's AI infrastructureWestern tech companies are also racing to build the infrastructure needed to power AI in India.
As AI companies scale up in India, they're bringing new forms of risk with them.

title: BBC 'deeply concerned' about journalist unable to leave Vietnam
summary:
BBC 'deeply concerned' about journalist unable to leave VietnamThe BBC said it was "deeply concerned" about the well-being of one its journalists who has been unable to leave Vietnam for several months.
The Vietnamese national travelled to the country to visit family and renew their passport, but the document and their ID card have been withheld and they have been subjected to "multiple days of questioning", the corporation said in a statement.
The BBC is urging Vietnamese authorities to allow the journalist to leave immediately and return to work by providing the renewed passport.
It comes as general secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam, To Lam, arrived in the UK on Tuesday, for a visit during which he is expected to meet Sir Keir Starmer.

title: Israel confirms identities of hostages' bodies returned by Hamas
summary:
Israel confirms identities of hostages' bodies returned by Hamas13 hours ago Share Save David Gritten Jerusalem Share SaveReuters The Israeli military said Sahar Baruch (L) and Amiram Cooper (R) were killed by their captorsIsrael has confirmed the identities of two deceased hostages whose bodies it received from Hamas via the Red Cross in Gaza on Thursday.
The Hostages and Missing Families Forum in Israel demanded that all 11 Israeli and foreign deceased hostages still in Gaza be returned immediately by Hamas in line with the US-brokered ceasefire agreement.
The Israeli military said it estimated Amiram was murdered in captivity in February 2024, but that final conclusions will be made upon completion of a post-mortem.
The Israeli military said it estimated that he was murdered in captivity on 8 December 2023, and that it was awaiting the results of a post-mortem.
The Hostages and Missing Families Forum, which represents many hostages' families, said: "There are no words to express the depth of this pain."

title: America’s Impending Population Collapse
summary:
In the buoyant decades after World War II, net migration was low compared with the Ellis Island era of the early 20th century, but still positive.
It may be powerful enough to bring net migration down to zero, perhaps for some time.
We know because the United States has tried it before.
The number of native-born American workers in prime age has been stuck since 2013, and it is not expected to start growing.
The United States has always been a nation of expansion: It has never before experienced population shrinkage year after year.

title: Washington’s ‘Blob’ is helping whitewash war crimes in Sudan
summary:
This apparatus not only sustains conservative inertia but also defines the limits of what is considered possible in policy.
RSF militiamen carry out their atrocities with confidence, knowing that responsibility will be blurred and its burden scattered across the parties.
This discourse serves as an overture to the Blob, leveraging shared geopolitical priorities to portray the RSF as a pragmatic partner in regional stability.
This fundamental distinction highlights the Blob’s contrived equivalence, conflating legitimate state-to-state engagements with the illicit empowerment of atrocity perpetrators.
These networks are often presented in Blob forums as “civilian stakeholders” or “pragmatic moderates”, sidelining authentic grassroots entities inside Sudan.

title: China's rare earth export delay offers US a chance to weaken Beijing's grip on the market
summary:
But it will be hard to undercut China's stranglehold on the market.
The restrictions China imposed on rare earths this year have been a key issue in the trade talks between Beijing and Washington.
China accounts for nearly 70% of the world’s rare earths mining.
It also controls roughly 90% of global rare earths processing.
The West is making progressIan Lange, who is an economics professor who focuses on rare earths at the Colorado School of Mines, said he thinks the U.S. and its allies can make significant progress in a year’s time to lessen China’s dominance of the rare earths market.

title: Hotel lockdowns and honeymoon hit as Britons caught up in Hurricane Melissa
summary:

They are among the UK nationals on the island bracing themselves for what could be the most powerful storm ever to hit Jamaica.
Hurricane Melissa is forecast to bring "catastrophic and life-threatening conditions, and made landfall with with winds of up to 185mph (297km/h).

title: ‘Last-ditch push’: Pakistan-Afghanistan talks falter amid deep mistrust
summary:

A fraught friendshipHistorically, Pakistan was long perceived as the primary patron of the Afghan Taliban.
Although independent from the Afghan Taliban, the two groups are ideologically aligned.

title: IndiGo, Air India CEOs back government’s cautious stance on market access to large foreign airlines
summary:

Story continues below this adWilson also said that the issue of market access and imbalances doesn’t pertain to just bilateral air traffic rights, but also the shortage of slots at busy airports.
He argued that various large overseas carriers were able to secure slots long ago, while carriers like Air India that are “starting somewhat later” don’t enjoy the same luxury.
The Indian government and major Indian carriers like Air India and IndiGo have ambitions to have more direct international connectivity from India and to turn the country into an international aviation hub.
The India-Dubai bilateral air services agreement has not been revised in over a decade.

title: Coffee Break: Armed Madhouse – Gunboat Stupidity
summary:
The Littoral Combat Ship (LCS), conceived in the early 2000s as a sleek, fast instrument of military force in contested littoral waters, is now being quietly retired.
This article explains the convergent failures of the LCS program and the associated coercive diplomacy concept.
The two designs, the Freedom-class littoral combat ship monohull and the Independence-class littoral combat ship trimaran, represented sharply different engineering philosophies.
The Yemen Missile Campaign: Proof of Failed Gunboat DiplomacyIf the Littoral Combat Ship program represents the conceptual failure of gunboat diplomacy, the Yemen missile campaign represents its operational collapse.
Acknowledging LCS FailureThe U.S. Navy has quietly acknowledged the failure of the Littoral Combat Ship (LCS) program.
